name: Smiðja Parliamentary Offices
subtitle: 80% material circularity with 100% local Icelandic stone - parliament as circular economy symbol
data_source: Nordic Best Practice Catalogue + Studio Granda + Alþingi

executive_summary.headline: 80% material circularity through local stone reuse - Iceland's parliament demonstrates national commitment to sustainability
key_achievements: 100% local Icelandic stone (basalt from hospital demolition + reopened quarry)
100% stone offcuts upcycled to terrazzo-effect meeting room floors
Classic Icelandic chairs restored from Parliament's historical collection
Aluminum art installation from production byproduct
LCA completed via One Click LCA
Iceland Design Awards 2024 - Place of the Year
Mies van der Rohe Award 2026 nomination
executive_summary.why_strong: Smiðja demonstrates that high circularity (80%) can be achieved through creative local sourcing. The project's symbolic significance - parliament building using materials from hospital demolition - represents national circular economy ambitions.
executive_summary.why_tier: Completeness score 82/100 (Grade A). Good LCA documentation but specific CO2 reduction not published. Strong circular features documentation.

materials.description: Basalt stone from Landspítali hospital demolition - facade and interior
Red stone from reopened abandoned local quarry
100% of stone offcuts from facade cutting reused as terrazzo-effect flooring in 6 meeting rooms
Classic Icelandic chairs from Parliament's existing collection restored
Reclaimed doors from Icelandic recycling centers
Rooftop art installation using aluminum production byproduct ('red thread')

circularity.methodology: Material reuse assessment from Nordic LCA study

co2_reduction.note: LCA completed but specific reduction not published. Expected better than benchmark (9.1 kg CO2e/m²/year)

awards.name: Iceland Design Awards - Place of the Year

key_insights: Local stone reuse achieves 80% circularity even with challenging geology
Icelandic basalt is brittle (only 30% yield when cutting)
Design integration of waste streams (offcuts→floors) maximizes value
Pushback from engineers preferring imported stone was overcome
challenges: LCA tools lack factors for Icelandic stone - default to Norwegian references
Brittle basalt requires careful cutting methodology

sources.name: Nordic Best Practice Catalogue - Smiðja LCA Entry

narrative.driver: Parliament building to symbolize Iceland's commitment to sustainability using local resources.
narrative.approach: All stone from Iceland - reclaimed hospital demolition or reopened quarry. 100% offcuts upcycled to meeting room floors. Design philosophy based on geological strata.
narrative.significance: National symbol of circular economy commitment. 80% circularity demonstrates local material viability.
narrative.legacy: Stone from Smiðja reused in Háteigsvegur 59 - emerging circular ecosystem.
